title: example
text: examples real data used package ‘psych’ dataset “holzinger.swineford” series demographics scores different subtests measuring intelligence 301 subjects. package retrieved ‘library’, dataset can opened using ‘data(“name dataset”)’. simplicity decided rename shorter name.
code: library(psych) library(psychTools) data("holzinger.swineford") Holz <- holzinger.swineford

title: example
text: following chunk want get critical value correlation two cognitive sub-tests 301 subjects. can ‘critical’ function: First, ‘cor.test’ function used two variables interest newly created object put ‘critical’ function. output add, underneath usual output ‘cor.test’ function, absolute critical value (rc), representing smallest significant effect.
code: cc <- cor.test(Holz$t01_visperc, Holz$t02_cubes) critical(cc) #>  #>  Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  Holz$t01_visperc and Holz$t02_cubes #> t = 5.3852, df = 299, p-value = 1.467e-07 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  0.1907064 0.3970530 #> sample estimates: #>       cor  #> 0.2973479  #>  #> |== Critical Value ==|  #> |rc| = 0.1130784

title: example
text: Now want know critical value t-test comparing boys girls cognitive variable visual perception. case, can easily done procedure using ‘t.test’ function: output now gives wider range values: cohen’s d calculated data (d), critical cohen’s d (dc), numerator formula critical cohen’s d (bc), cohen’s d adjusted small samples (g) critical cohen’s d adjusted small samples (gc).
code: tt <- t.test(Holz$t01_visperc [ Holz$female == 1], Holz$t01_visperc [ Holz$female == 2]) critical(tt) #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  Holz$t01_visperc[Holz$female == 1] and Holz$t01_visperc[Holz$female == 2] #> t = 1.4095, df = 298.9, p-value = 0.1597 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.06419229  0.38823118 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  4.314090  4.152071  #>  #> |== Effect Size and Critical Value ==|  #> d = 0.1623665 dc = ± 0.2269609 bc = ± 0.2262117  #> g = 0.1619587 gc = ± 0.2263909

title: example
text: Now want calculate critical coefficients linear model visual perception predicted age. can wrapping ‘critical’ function ‘summary’ function: output, column appear next usual column estimates reporting critical values intercept predictor(s).
code: ll <- lm( t01_visperc ~ ageyr , data = Holz) summary(critical(ll)) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = t01_visperc ~ ageyr, data = Holz) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -3.6019 -0.6591 -0.0019  0.6266  3.1124  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate |Critical Estimate| Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)  4.97325             1.41113    0.71706   6.936 2.51e-11 *** #> ageyr       -0.05714             0.10822    0.05499  -1.039      0.3     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.001 on 299 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.003597,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.0002647  #> F-statistic: 1.079 on 1 and 299 DF,  p-value: 0.2997

title: example
text: next examples show use package’s functions calculate critical values prospective framework.

what: Critical t value from sample size
title: example
text: Let us say want calculate critical t value t-test sample 1200 subjects group, following chunk shows function ‘critical_t2s’: function requires specify hypothesis “less”, “greater” “two.tailed”. output can find critical d critical g, cohen’s d adjusted small samples.
code: n <- 1200 critical_t2s(n1 = n , n2 = n , hypothesis = "less") #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t = t, n1 = n1, n2 = n2, se = se, conf.level = #> conf.level, : When var.equal = FALSE the critical value calculated from t #> assume sd1 = sd2! #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t = t, n1 = n1, n2 = n2, se = se, conf.level = #> conf.level, : When t is NULL, d cannot be computed, returning NA #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t = t, n1 = n1, n2 = n2, se = se, conf.level = #> conf.level, : When se = NULL bc cannot be computed, returning NA! #> $d #> [1] NA #>  #> $dc #> [1] 0.06717682 #>  #> $bc #> [1] NA #>  #> $se #> NULL #>  #> $df #> [1] 2398 #>  #> $gc #> [1] 0.06715581

what: Critical t value from sample size for a paired t-test.
title: example
text: Assuming want calculate critical value paired t-test (.e. pre-post treatment), can function ‘critical_t2sp’ following way: Specifying direction hypothesis confidence interval, function give output standardized (dzc) un-standardized (dc) critical cohen’s d, critical cohen’s d adjusted small samples standardized (gc) un-standardized (gzc).
code: n <- 15 critical_t2sp(n = n , hypothesis = "less", conf.level = .95) #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2sp(t = t, n = n, se = se, r12 = r12, hypothesis = #> hypothesis, : when t is NULL, dz and d cannot be computed, returning NA #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2sp(t = t, n = n, se = se, r12 = r12, hypothesis = #> hypothesis, : When se is NULL, bc cannot be computed, returning NA #> $dz #> [1] NA #>  #> $dzc #> [1] 0.4547683 #>  #> $d #> [1] NA #>  #> $dc #> [1] 0.6431395 #>  #> $bc #> [1] NA #>  #> $se #> NULL #>  #> $df #> [1] 14 #>  #> $gc #> [1] 0.6079519 #>  #> $gzc #> [1] 0.4298869

what: Critical value for a correlation from sample size
title: example
text: can done critical value correlation defined sample size ‘critical_cor’ function: , direction hypothesis test apply, either t-test z-test, specified. output return critical correlation value, degrees freedom type test used.

what: Critical value of a beta from a model from saple size
title: example
text: Let us say want know critical beta model, can use ‘critical_coef’ function shown following chunk: important specifying sample size, standard error estimate, p-value, confidence level hypothesis. output return critical beta test used.
code: n <- 170 critical_coef(seb = .1, n = n, p = .01, conf.level = .95, hypothesis = "less") #> $bc #> [1] 0.165392 #>  #> $test #> [1] "t"

what: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
text: goal criticalvalue …

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
text: can install development version criticalvalue like :
code: # require(devtools) devtools::install_github("filippogambarota/criticalvalue")

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
text: package production-ready thus test feature suggest clone download repository, open R Project load functions devtools::load_all().

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
text: basic example shows solve common problem:

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
text: can check results using:
code: # library(criticalvalue) # when the package will be ready devtools::load_all() # loading all functions for testing #> ℹ Loading criticalvalue  # t-test (welch)  x <- rnorm(30, 0.5, 1) y <- rnorm(30, 0, 1)  ttest <- t.test(x, y) critical(ttest) #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 1.57, df = 56.5, p-value = 0.12 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.12697  1.03569 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  0.487716  0.033355  #>  #> |== Effect Size and Critical Value ==|  #> d = 0.40418 |dc| = 0.51713 |bc| = 0.58133  #> g = 0.39879 |gc| = 0.51023  # t-test (standard)  ttest <- t.test(x, y, var.equal = TRUE) critical(ttest) #>  #>  Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 1.57, df = 58, p-value = 0.12 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.12665  1.03537 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  0.487716  0.033355  #>  #> |== Effect Size and Critical Value ==|  #> d = 0.40418 |dc| = 0.51684 |bc| = 0.58101  #> g = 0.39893 |gc| = 0.51012  # t-test (standard) with monodirectional hyp  ttest <- t.test(x, y, var.equal = TRUE, alternative = "less") critical(ttest) #>  #>  Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 1.57, df = 58, p-value = 0.94 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is less than 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>     -Inf 0.93954 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  0.487716  0.033355  #>  #> |== Effect Size and Critical Value ==|  #> d = 0.40418 dc = -0.43159 bc = -0.48518  #> g = 0.39893 gc = -0.42598  # within the t-test object saved from critical we have all the new values  ttest <- critical(ttest) str(ttest) #> List of 15 #>  $ statistic  : Named num 1.57 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "t" #>  $ parameter  : Named num 58 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "df" #>  $ p.value    : num 0.939 #>  $ conf.int   : num [1:2] -Inf 0.94 #>   ..- attr(*, "conf.level")= num 0.95 #>  $ estimate   : Named num [1:2] 0.4877 0.0334 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:2] "mean of x" "mean of y" #>  $ null.value : Named num 0 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "difference in means" #>  $ stderr     : num 0.29 #>  $ alternative: chr "less" #>  $ method     : chr " Two Sample t-test" #>  $ data.name  : chr "x and y" #>  $ g          : Named num 0.399 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "1" #>  $ gc         : Named num 0.426 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "1" #>  $ d          : num 0.404 #>  $ bc         : num 0.485 #>  $ dc         : num 0.432 #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:3] "critvalue" "ttest" "htest" ttest <- t.test(x, y) ttest <- critical(ttest)  t <- ttest$bc/ttest$stderr # critical numerator / standard error  # should be 0.05 (or alpha) (1 - pt(ttest$bc/ttest$stderr, ttest$parameter)) * 2 #> [1] 0.05

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
code: # cor.test ctest <- cor.test(x, y) critical(ctest) #>  #>  Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = -0.434, df = 28, p-value = 0.67 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.42940  0.28694 #> sample estimates: #>       cor  #> -0.081785  #>  #> |== Critical Value ==|  #> |rc| = 0.36101

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
code: # linear model (unstandardized) z <- rnorm(30) q <- rnorm(30)  dat <- data.frame(x, y, z, q) fit <- lm(y ~ x + q + z, data = dat) fit <- critical(fit) fit #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x + q + z, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)            x            q            z   #>      0.0261      -0.0606      -0.1595       0.1569   #>  #>  #> Critical |Coefficients|  #>  #> (Intercept)           x           q           z  #>     0.56091     0.48702     0.57990     0.54323 summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x + q + z, data = dat) #>  #> Residuals: #>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max  #> -1.959 -0.585 -0.247  0.481  3.209  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate |Critical Estimate| Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept)   0.0261              0.5609     0.2729    0.10     0.92 #> x            -0.0606              0.4870     0.2369   -0.26     0.80 #> q            -0.1595              0.5799     0.2821   -0.57     0.58 #> z             0.1569              0.5432     0.2643    0.59     0.56 #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.26 on 26 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.0272, Adjusted R-squared:  -0.085  #> F-statistic: 0.243 on 3 and 26 DF,  p-value: 0.866  # linear model (standardized) fit <- lm(y ~ x + q + z, data = dat) fit <- critical(fit, standardize = TRUE) fit #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x + q + z, data = D) #>  #> Coefficients: #>            (Intercept)                       x                       q   #>  0.0000000000000000024  -0.0515084809938952254  -0.1122834490871214147   #>                      z   #>  0.1226511806886874945   #>  #>  #> Critical |Coefficients|  #>  #> (Intercept)           x           q           z  #>     0.39091     0.41415     0.40820     0.42476 summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x + q + z, data = D) #>  #> Residuals: #>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max  #> -1.618 -0.483 -0.204  0.398  2.649  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                           Estimate    |Critical Estimate| #> (Intercept)  0.0000000000000000024  0.3909120122152270893 #> x           -0.0515084809938952254  0.4141515247927876620 #> q           -0.1122834490871214147  0.4082029527114897638 #> z            0.1226511806886874945  0.4247575870243170404 #>                         Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept)  0.1901758276316976304    0.00     1.00 #> x            0.2014816801000057778   -0.26     0.80 #> q            0.1985877433995782149   -0.57     0.58 #> z            0.2066414516080858910    0.59     0.56 #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.04 on 26 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.0272, Adjusted R-squared:  -0.085  #> F-statistic: 0.243 on 3 and 26 DF,  p-value: 0.866

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
code: require(metafor) #> Loading required package: metafor #> Loading required package: Matrix #> Loading required package: metadat #> Loading required package: numDeriv #>  #> Loading the 'metafor' package (version 4.0-0). For an #> introduction to the package please type: help(metafor) dat <- escalc(measure="RR", ai=tpos, bi=tneg, ci=cpos, di=cneg, data=dat.bcg) fit <- rma(yi, vi, mods=cbind(ablat, year), data=dat) critical(fit) #>  #> Mixed-Effects Model (k = 13; tau^2 estimator: REML) #>  #> tau^2 (estimated amount of residual heterogeneity):     0.1108 (SE = 0.0845) #> tau (square root of estimated tau^2 value):             0.3328 #> I^2 (residual heterogeneity / unaccounted variability): 71.98% #> H^2 (unaccounted variability / sampling variability):   3.57 #> R^2 (amount of heterogeneity accounted for):            64.63% #>  #> Test for Residual Heterogeneity: #> QE(df = 10) = 28.3251, p-val = 0.0016 #>  #> Test of Moderators (coefficients 2:3): #> QM(df = 2) = 12.2043, p-val = 0.0022 #>  #> Model Results: #>  #>          estimate       se     zval    pval     ci.lb    ci.ub      #> intrcpt   -3.5455  29.0959  -0.1219  0.9030  -60.5724  53.4814      #> ablat     -0.0280   0.0102  -2.7371  0.0062   -0.0481  -0.0080  **  #> year       0.0019   0.0147   0.1299  0.8966   -0.0269   0.0307      #>  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #>         |critical estimate| #> intrcpt            62.85783 #> ablat               0.02211 #> year                0.03172

title: Compute Critical Effect Size Values From Common Statistics Models
code: x <- rnorm(30, 0.5, 1) y <- rnorm(30, 0, 1)  ttest <- t.test(x, y)  m1 <- mean(x) m2 <- mean(y) sd1 <- sd(x) sd2 <- sd(y) n1 <- n2 <- 30  critical_t2s(m1, m2, sd1 = sd1, sd2 = sd2, n1 = n1, n2 = n2) #> $d #> [1] 0.5146 #>  #> $dc #> [1] 0.51901 #>  #> $bc #> [1] 0.52147 #>  #> $df #> [1] 48.481 #>  #> $g #> [1] 0.50659 #>  #> $gc #> [1] 0.51093  critical_t2s(t = ttest$statistic, se = ttest$stderr, n1 = n1, n2 = n2) #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t, n1, n2, se, conf.level, hypothesis, var.equal): #> When var.equal = FALSE the critical value calculated from t assume sd1 = sd2! #> $d #>      t  #> 0.5146  #>  #> $dc #> [1] 0.51684 #>  #> $bc #> [1] 0.51929 #>  #> $df #> [1] 58 #>  #> $g #>       t  #> 0.50791  #>  #> $gc #> [1] 0.51012  critical_t2s(t = ttest$statistic, n1 = n1, n2 = n2) #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t, n1, n2, se, conf.level, hypothesis, var.equal): #> When var.equal = FALSE the critical value calculated from t assume sd1 = sd2! #> Warning in crit_from_t_t2s(t, n1, n2, se, conf.level, hypothesis, var.equal): #> When se = NULL bc cannot be computed, returning NA! #> $d #>      t  #> 0.5146  #>  #> $dc #> [1] 0.51684 #>  #> $bc #> [1] NA #>  #> $df #> [1] 58 #>  #> $g #>       t  #> 0.50791  #>  #> $gc #> [1] 0.51012

title: crit_from_data_t1s — crit_from_data_t1s
text: function allows calculate cohen's d critical d one samples t-test given mean, variance sample numerosity, specifying standard error, degrees freedom, confidence level interval direction hypothesis.

title: crit_from_data_t1s — crit_from_data_t1s
code: crit_from_data_t1s(m, s, n, se = NULL, df = NULL, conf.level, hypothesis)

title: crit_from_data_t1s — crit_from_data_t1s
text: m mean sample. s number corresponding variance. n number corresponding sample size. se number corresponding standard error. df degrees freedom. conf.level confidence level interval. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed").

title: crit_from_data_t1s — crit_from_data_t1s
text: output returns "d" cohen's d, critical d minimum value get significant result given sample, "bc" numerator formula d calculated "df" degrees freedom.

title: crit_from_data_t2s — crit_from_data_t2s
text: function allows calculate cohen's d critical d given mean two groups, standard deviation means sample size two groups, specifying confidence level interval, direction hypothesis, standard error, degrees freedom variance parameter.

title: crit_from_data_t2s — crit_from_data_t2s
code: crit_from_data_t2s(   m1,   m2,   sd1,   sd2,   n1,   n2,   conf.level,   hypothesis,   se = NULL,   df = NULL,   var.equal = FALSE )

title: crit_from_data_t2s — crit_from_data_t2s
text: m1 number representing mean group 1. m2 number representing mean group 2. sd1 number representing standard deviation group 1. sd2 number representing standard deviation group 2. n1 number corresponding sample size group 1. n2 number corresponding sample size group 2. conf.level confidence level interval. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed"). se number corresponding standard error. df degrees freedom. var.equal logical variable indicating whether treat two variances equal.

title: crit_from_data_t2s — crit_from_data_t2s
text: output returns "d" cohen's d, critical d minimum value get significant result given sample, "bc" numerator formula d calculated "df" degrees freedom.

title: Compute critical effect size values for a range of different objects — critical

title: Compute critical effect size values for a range of different objects — critical

title: critical_coef — critical_coef
text: function allows calculate critical beta.

title: critical_coef — critical_coef
code: critical_coef(   seb,   n = NULL,   p = NULL,   df = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   hypothesis = c("two.sided", "greater", "less"),   test = c("t", "z") )

title: critical_coef — critical_coef
text: seb numeric vector standard error regression coefficients. n number corresponding sample size. p number parameters. df degrees freedom. conf.level confidence level set confidence interval, default set 0.95. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed"). test parameter specify test apply, either "t" t-test "z" z-test.

title: critical_coef — critical_coef
text: output returns critical beta test used (either t z).

title: critical_cor — critical_cor
text: function allows calculate critical correlation value.

title: critical_cor — critical_cor
code: critical_cor(   r = NULL,   n,   conf.level = 0.95,   hypothesis = c("two.sided", "greater", "less"),   test = c("t", "z") )

title: critical_cor — critical_cor
text: r number corresponding correlation coefficient. n number corresponding sample size. conf.level confidence level set confidence interval, default set 0.95. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed"). test parameter specify test apply, either "t" t-test "z" z-test.

title: critical_cor — critical_cor
text: output returns critical correlation value, degrees freedom test used (either t z).

title: critical_t1s — critical_t1s

title: critical_t1s — critical_t1s
code: critical_t1s(   m = NULL,   s = NULL,   t = NULL,   n,   se = NULL,   hypothesis = c("two.sided", "greater", "less"),   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: critical_t1s — critical_t1s
text: m number representing mean group. s Variance t t value. n number corresponding sample size. se number corresponding standard error. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed"). conf.level confidence level set confidence interval, default set 0.95.

title: critical_t1s — critical_t1s
text: output returns, based inserted values, mean, variance, confidence interval hypothesis t-value, numerosity, standard error, confidence interval hypothesis.

title: critical_t2s — critical_t2s

code: critical_t2s(   m1 = NULL,   m2 = NULL,   t = NULL,   sd1 = NULL,   sd2 = NULL,   n1,   n2,   se = NULL,   df = NULL,   var.equal = FALSE,   hypothesis = c("two.sided", "greater", "less"),   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: critical_t2s — critical_t2s
text: m1 number representing mean group 1. m2 number representing mean group 2. t t value. sd1 number representing standard deviation group 1. sd2 number representing standard deviation group 2. n1 number corresponding sample size group 1. n2 number corresponding sample size group 2. se number corresponding standard error. df degrees freedom. var.equal logical variable indicating whether treat two variances equal. hypothesis character string indicating alternative hypothesis ("less", "greater" "two.tailed"). conf.level confidence level set confidence interval, default set 0.95.
